Verborum

Verborum#

Devices#

  • Anacoluthon: A discontinuity of expression within a sentence, a form in which there is a logical or grammatical incoherence.

  • Anadiplosis: When words at the end of one clause are repeated near the beginning of the following clause.

  • Anaphora: The repetition of words at the beginning of successive clauses.

  • Anastrophe: An inversion of the grammatical order of words or clauses.

  • Antimetabole: The repetition of words in successive clauses, but in transposed order.

  • Aposiopesis: An expression left unsatisfied or incomplete.

  • Chiasmus: Grammatical forms repeated in reverse order.

  • Epanalepsis: The same words used at the end of a clause are used at the beginning of a preceding clause

  • Epistrophe: The repetition of words at the end of successive clauses.

  • Hypozeuxis: An expression whose every clause has its own independent subject and predicate.

  • Hysteron Proteron: An expression in which what should come last is put first.

  • Symploce: The repetition of both the words at the beginning and end of successive clauses.

  • Tmesis: The separation of parts of a compound word by an intervening words.

Anacoluthon#

with up so floating many bells down

—anyone lived in a pretty how town

She’s all states, and all princes, I,

Nothing else is.

—The Sun Rising

Anadiplosis#

The years to come seemed waste of breath,

A waste of breath the years behind

—An Irishman Airman Foresees His Death

The eyes that fix you in a formulated phrase,

And when I am formulated, sprawling on a pin,

When I am pinned and wriggling on the wall,

—The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock

Anaphora#

Fear not the waking world, my mortal,

Fear not the flat, synthetic blood,

—All All and All

We are the hollow men

We are the stuffed men

—The Hollow Men

Anastrophe#

With fruit the vines that round the thatch-eves run

—To Autumn

May the last Adam’s blood my soul embrace

—Hymn to God, My God, In Sickness

Antimetabole#

None yet found.

Aposiopesis#

For Thine is

Life is

For Thine is the

—The Hollow Men

Chiasmus#

Beauty is truth, truth beauty

—Ode on a Grecian Urn

Epanalepsis#

None yet found.

Epistrophe#

A crowd flowed over London Bridge, so many,

I had not thought death had undone so many.

—The Wasteland

Hypozeuxis#

None yet found.

Hysteron Proteron#

None yet found.

Symploce#

The yellow fog that rubs its back upon the window-panes,

The yellow smoke that rubs its muzzle on the window-panes

—The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock

Tmesis#

None yet found.
